titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thomas Howard Ruger Papers
titlestmt.author: Stephanie Bredbenner

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:15

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, reports, printed material, and maps that document the military career and personal life of United States Army general Thomas Howard Ruger, focusing on his years in Montana, the Dakotas, and Missouri, 1879-1895. The collection contains significant documentation of the relationship between Native Americans and the United States government, especially the Lakota, Cheyenne, Kiowa, Arapaho, Crow, and Chiricahua Apache communities. Correspondence and records from Ruger's post as commander of the Department of Dakota document actions taken by United States Army personnel to track Ghost Dance practitioners (including Kicking Bear and Sitting Bull) and to quell the Ghost Dance religious movement during the Ghost Dance War, 1890-1891. The papers also contain correspondence and reports documenting Ruger's and others' reactions to the death of Sitting Bull and the Wounded Knee Massacre. Four cloth maps document geographic details of Sioux reservations in North and South Dakota, and the site of the Wounded Knee Massacre. The collection includes letters from United States Army generals William T. Sherman and Nelson A. Miles, Lakota leader Sitting Bull, United States secretaries of war William Crowinshield Endicott and Redfield Proctor, and United States president Benjamin Harrison.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from William Reese Co.(Cowan's sale, 2009 June 24, lots 283, 284 and 285) on the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 2009.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Professional Papers, 1865-1907. II. Maps, 1890-1891. III. Personal Correspondence, 1861-1907. IV. Ruger Family Papers, 1821-1958.

bioghist.head: Thomas Howard Ruger (1833-1907)
bioghist.p: Thomas Howard Ruger (1833-1907) was born in Lima, New York and graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1854. He saw active duty in the United States Army during the Civil War and in the Reconstruction South, eventually rising to the rank of brigadier general. He was the superintendent of the United States Military Academy, 1871-1876, Commander of the Department of the South, 1876-1878, Commander of the District of Montana, 1879-1886, Commander of the Department of Dakota, 1886-1891, Commander of the Department of California, 1891-1894, Commander of the Military Division of the Missouri, 1894-1895, and Commander of the Department of the East, 1895-1897. Ruger was promoted to major general in 1895 and retired from the Army in 1897. Ruger died on June 3, 1907, in Stamford, Connecticut. He married Helen Lydia Moore in 1857 and they had two daughters, Helen Ruger Hay and Anna Ruger.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Thomas Howard Ruger Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit. The Thomas Howard Ruger papers was comprehensively reprocessed in 2017. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards. For more information, please refer to the Beinecke Manuscript Unit Processing Manual.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, reports, printed material, and maps that document the military career and personal life of United States Army general Thomas Howard Ruger, focusing on his years in Montana, the Dakotas, and Missouri, 1879-1895. The collection contains significant documentation of the relationship between Native Americans and the United States government, especially the Lakota, Cheyenne, Kiowa, Arapaho, Crow, and Chiricahua Apache communities. Correspondence and records from Ruger's post as commander of the Department of Dakota document actions taken by United States Army personnel to track Ghost Dance practitioners (including Kicking Bear and Sitting Bull) and to quell the Ghost Dance religious movement during the Ghost Dance War, 1890-1891. The papers also contain correspondence and reports documenting Ruger's and others' reactions to the death of Sitting Bull and the Wounded Knee Massacre. Four cloth maps document geographic details of Sioux reservations in North and South Dakota, and the site of the Wounded Knee Massacre. The collection includes letters from United States Army generals William T. Sherman and Nelson A. Miles, Lakota leader Sitting Bull, United States secretaries of war William Crowinshield Endicott and Redfield Proctor, and United States president Benjamin Harrison.

The collection includes correspondence, reports, and other records documenting the Crow War of 1887, when Ruger served as the commander of the Department of Dakota. Papers from Ruger's post at the Military Division of the Missouri document the treatment of the Chiricahua Apache prisoners of war held at Fort Sill, 1894-1895. The collection contains officers' reports of armed conflicts with Native American tribes, lists of tribal leaders and Native Americans suspected of unrest, and records of Native Americans enlisting in the United States Army as scouts. There are also transcriptions of speeches by Native Americans and accounts of Native Americans' grievances against white settlers, Indian agents, and the United States government.

Other military papers document Ruger's term as president of the Military Service Institution of the United States, 1901-1907. Personal correspondence documents Ruger's family life and travels, including extensive correspondence with his wife and daughters. Family papers include the correspondence of Ruger's wife Helen Moore Ruger, daughters Helen Ruger Hay and Anna Ruger, and son-in-law Thomas A. H. Hay. Other family papers include genealogical records, wills, and correspondence relating to Ruger's family after his death.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Thomas Howard Ruger Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into four subseries: District of Montana Post, Department of Dakota Post, Military Division of the Missouri Post, and Other Professional Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, reports, and other papers documenting Thomas Howard Ruger's career in the United States Army, including his posts as Commander of the District of Montana, 1879-1886, Commander of the Department of Dakota, 1886-1891, Commander of the Department of California, 1891-1894, Commander of the Military Division of the Missouri, 1894-1895, and Commander of the Department of the East, 1895-1897. Includes records of the Ghost Dance War and Wounded Knee Massacre, as well as documentation of the Chiricahua Apache prisoners of war held at Fort Sill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a report on Tongue River Agency, a Commission of Military Affairs survey, and correspondence documenting the construction of Fort Assinniboine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thomas Howard Ruger's notebook during his post as commander of the District of Montana. Includes notes on the Blackfeet Agency, lists of local Native American tribal leaders, and scouting maps of the Black Hills and Badlands. Includes autograph letters from William T. Sherman and Nelson A. Miles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics include the construction of Fort Assinniboine and hostilities with Sioux tribes at Fort Belknap Agency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes orders, invitations, circulars, miscellaneous correspondence, and a certificate of assay for ore mined in Montana.

did.unittitle: School of Application for Infantry and Cavalry

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes records relating to the regulations, rules, and curriculum of the school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Records and correspondence documenting Thomas Howard Ruger's promotion to brigadier general and assignment to the Department of Dakota.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and memoranda documenting the Crow War of 1887. Includes information about Crow camps during the conflict and Crow leaders such as Deaf Bull, Crazy Head, and Sword Bearer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence relating to the Crow War, reports of military strategy and troop movements during the Crow War, a list of Crow leaders and families involved in the war, and a copy of a speech by Crow leaders Plenty Coups and Pretty Eagle.

did.unittitle: Correspondence concerning Crow, Cheyenne, and Sioux Tribes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence concerning government and intertribal relations with Crow, Cheyenne, and Sioux tribes during and after the Crow War. Includes correspondence concerning Ruger's proposal that Native Americans enlist in the United States Army as scouts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Records documenting Thomas Howard Ruger's special orders from United States secretary of war Redfield Proctor and United States president Benjamin Harrison. Topics include the Cheyenne Commission and courts of inquiry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence concerning the United States Army's management of Yellowstone Park, including the presence of troops in Yellowstone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence concerning the Ghost Dance movement, including the history of the movement, Thomas Howard Ruger's reports of a visit to Standing Rock Agency, the United States government's assessment of the origins and prevalence of the movement, and a list of Native American leaders of the movement. Includes typescript copies of letters from United States president Benjamin Harrison and Lakota leader Sitting Bull.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence concerning the Ghost Dance War, particularly relating to Sitting Bull. Includes orders for Sitting Bull's arrest, correspondence concerning the movements of United States troops and Sitting Bull in December 1890, and accounts of Sitting Bull's death. Also includes a list of Lakota tribal leaders, the locations of their camps, and the number of people in their bands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence and reports concerning the Ghost Dance War, written and received during Thomas Howard Ruger's post at the Department of California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports and correspondence from multiple United States Army officers in the wake of the Wounded Knee Massacre. Includes accounts of troop movements and orders in the days before the massacre on December 29, 1890. Includes conflicting accounts and a dispute between two officers about the surrender and imprisonment of the Lakota at Fort Sully.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains reports documenting United States military action before and after the Wounded Knee Massacre, including an officer's report and a report about an officer who died during the campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics include infantry drill regulations, the division of Sioux agencies into multiple reservations, and Thomas Howard Ruger's comments on proposed changes to the officer promotion system of the United States Army. Includes letters from United States secretaries of war Redfield Proctor and William Crowninshield Endicott.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics include the appointment of a commander for the Infantry and Cavalry School of Application and Thomas Howard Ruger's appointment to command the Military Division of the Pacific and the Department of California.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook of Clippings about the Ghost Dance War
Military Division of the Missouri Post
Cheyenne and Arapaho Agency Crimes and Grievances

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a list of grievances raised by the Native Americans of Cheyenne and Arapaho Agency against white settlers and an account of crimes committed by white settlers and Native Americans at Cheyenne and Arapaho Agency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports about the population, resources, land, and rations of Cheyenne and Arapaho Agency.

did.unittitle: Correspondence concerning Apache Prisoners of War at Fort Sill

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence concerning several hundred Chiricahua Apache prisoners of war, including their transportation to Fort Sill and the United States government's provisions for them, including shelter, food, clothing, tools, and education for the children. Includes letters from Nelson A. Miles.

did.unittitle: Correspondence concerning Kiowa, Comanche, and Apache near Fort Sill

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence concerning Apache, Kiowa, and Comanche tribes near Fort Sill, including recommendations for an increased Indian police force.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes reports on relations between Native Americans and white settlers in Oklahoma and correspondence concerning the Kiowa, Comanche, Cheyenne, Arapaho, and Wichita tribes. Includes a memorandum entitled "In Regard to the Troubles in the Indian Territory" and a list of the tribes, Native American population, and Indian agents of every Native American reservation in the Military Division of the Missouri.

did.unittitle: Military Division of the Missouri Orders and Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Orders and general correspondence during Thomas Howard Ruger's post at the Military Division of the Missouri. Topics include wells at Fort Reno and Thomas Howard Ruger's promotion to major general.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three newspaper clippings about the Chickasaw tribe and train robberies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, reports, and financial records from Thomas Howard Ruger's other military posts, including his service during the Civil War, 1864-1865, the Department of the South, 1876-1878, the Department of California, 1890-1891, and the Department of the East, 1895-1897. Includes miscellaneous professional papers, orders, and correspondence, including invitations, circulars, and correspondence concerning Ruger's retirement from the United States Army.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes receipts, bills, checks, financial correspondence, and quartermaster records.

did.unittitle: Department of the South Orders and Correspondence
Department of California Orders and Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics include drill regulations, financial records, invitations, and the boundary between Fort Canby and Cape Disappointment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics include Thomas Howard Ruger's command of the Department of the Columbia and the possibility of war with Great Britain in 1892.

did.unittitle: Department of California Reports and Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics include the appointment of messengers, invitations, firing practice, and reports on infantry regulations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes invitations and correspondence concerning the United States Army Signal Corps.

did.unittitle: Letters of Congratulations on Promotion to Major General
Letters of Congratulations on Promotion to Major General
Correspondence concerning a Confederate Memorial in Chicago
Department of the East Orders and Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics include infantry drills, machine gun regulations, the appointment of messengers and clerks, and invitations.

did.unittitle: Correspondence concerning Chinese Ambassador Li Hongzhang's Visit to the United States
Preparations for War with Great Britain

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, reports, and orders concerning preparations for a possible war with Great Britain during the Venezuelan Crisis of 1895-1896.

did.unittitle: New York Chief of Police Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence concerning Mayor of New York City William Lafayette Strong's offer to appoint Thomas Howard Ruger as the chief of police for New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include invitations, correspondence concerning Thomas Howard Ruger's international travel, and Ruger's passport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes invitations and nominations from the American Institute of Civics and the American Forestry Association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics include the Spanish-American War, the use of shoulder rifles in the United States Army, and Thomas Howard Ruger's proposal that retired Army officers return to active duty during the Spanish-American War.

did.unittitle: Society of the Army of Ohio Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most likely a diplomatic gift from Chinese ambassador Li Hongzhang's visit to the United States in 1896.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four cyanotype cloth maps documenting United States Army forts and Native American reservations during the Ghost Dance War and Wounded Knee Massacre, 1890-1891.

did.unittitle: Map of Country Comprising Forts Meade, Custer, Keogh, and McKenney
Map of Country Comprising the Sioux Indian Reservations in North and South Dakota
Scene of the Fight with Big Foot's Band (2 copies)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thomas Howard Ruger's personal correspondence, primarily with his wife Helen Moore Ruger and daughters Helen Ruger Hay and Anna Ruger. Other correspondents include Ruger's father, Thomas Jefferson Ruger; brother, William Ruger; and sisters, Adelaide Ruger Dunbar and Cornelia Ruger Pease.

did.unittitle: Ruger, Thomas Howard, Letters to Helen Ruger Hay
Ruger, Thomas Howard, Letters to Anna Ruger
Ruger, Thomas Howard, Letters to Helen Moore Ruger
Ruger, Thomas Howard, Letters to Helen Moore Ruger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, wills, and other papers documenting the Ruger, Hay, Dickinson, and Wilson families in Ireland, England, and the United States. Includes Thomas Howard Ruger and Helen Moore Ruger's marriage certificate and letters of condolence after Thomas Howard Ruger's death in 1907.

did.unittitle: Dickinson, Annie Wilson Hay, Will and Probate
Hay, Helen Ruger and Thomas A. H. Hay, Marriage Certificate and Correspondence
Ruger, Helen Moore and Thomas Howard Ruger, Marriage Certificate

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Deeds, indentures, correspondence, and other papers concerning John Wilson (1803-1840), Alexander Wilson (1809-1884), and Jacob B. Odenwelder (1809-1884).

did.unittitle: Wilson, Alexander, United States Naturalization Certificate
Wilson, Alexander and James Wilson, Correspondence
